intro: Heliophytum persicariifolium, commonly known as the Persian carnation, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Boraginaceae and is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and showy, pink or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun, exhibiting a compact, bushy growth habit. Its flowers are arranged in dense clusters and bloom in late spring to early summer, making it a striking addition to rock gardens and alpine landscapes. Due to its ornamental value and adaptability, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens with well-drained soil and adequate sunlight.
